page.title: 04ECOLOGY
page.content: Conservation 'Canal Shardlow' is designated a conservation area with the aim of re-deploying existing facilities. Shardlow became an important inland port about 1761 with the building of the Trent and Mersey Canal, inspired by Josiah Wedgewood, the famous potter and built by James Brindley. Warehouses were built to store goods to be trans shipped from the canal narrow boats to the larger barges on the Rivers Trent and Derwent. Inlets were constructed to provide additional wharf space with supporting crafts such as rope making, smithying and crane buidling. Shardlow's prosperity declined in the mid 19th century when the railway took away the traffic from the canals. Bothe Hall Old Sawley is a Grade 2 listed building.
